nl.strohalm.cyclos.entities.reports

Class StatisticalNumber

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Number
      • nl.strohalm.cyclos.entities.reports.StatisticalNumber
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<StatisticalNumber>

    public class StatisticalNumber
extends java.lang.Number
implements java.lang.Comparable<StatisticalNumber>
    A convenient way to store the numerical results of the statistics. As the presentation of statistical results may take various forms, such as "3.12 +/- 1.76", "12" or "34%". This class can handle all these formats. It does not provide a toString method, as the settings with the application's NumberFormat are not easily accessible from cyclos3. The rendering in jsp's is taken care of in the FormatTag.java class.
    Author:
    Rinke
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • StatisticalNumber

        public StatisticalNumber(double value)
        Most simple constructor, creating numbers presented as integers. To be used for the most simple form, a single int like "12".
        Parameters:
        value - a double which is the value to be assigned to the object

      • StatisticalNumber

        public StatisticalNumber(double value,
                 byte precision)
        Constructor for simple decimal numbers like "6.234".
        Parameters:

        precision - the number of digits after the decimal point.

      • StatisticalNumber

        public StatisticalNumber(double value,
                 java.lang.Double error,
                 byte precision)
        Constructor for a StatisticalNumber with a value and an error indication. This constructor must be used for numbers taking the form "12.12 � 2.76"
        Parameters:
        value - a double indicating the value
        error - a Double indicating the error, so the number after the � sign. This is the only param which can take the value null.
        precision - a byte indicating the number of digits after the decimal point

      • StatisticalNumber

        public StatisticalNumber(double value,
                 java.lang.Double lowerBound,
                 java.lang.Double upperBound,
                 byte precision)
        Constructor for a StatisticalNumber with a value and error indication, specifically designed for a-symmetrical error bars. In this case, the error field will be left empty, and only the lowerBound and upperBound fields will be set. The number will be printed as "12.12 (10.0 - 17.2)". For this type of StatisticalNumber, hasErrorBars() returns true, but hasSymmetricalErrorBars returns false
        Parameters:
        value - a double indicating the value
        lowerBound - a Double indicating the lower value of the error range
        upperBound - a Double indicating the upper value of the error range
        precision - a byte indicating the number of digits after the decimal point.

    • Method Detail

      • createNullPvalue

        public static StatisticalNumber createNullPvalue()
        A factory method for the creation of a pValue which could not be created due to the fact that n-values were too small.
        Returns:
        a StatisitcalNumber with invalid pvalue.

      • createPercentage

        public static StatisticalNumber createPercentage(java.lang.Double value)
        a factory method for the creation of numbers representing percentages.
        Parameters:
        value - a Double representing the percentage. This parameter may be null, meaning that the percentage cannot be calculated (for example in case of growth from 0 to 0).
        Returns:
        a StatisticalNumber which will be interpreted as a percentage, that is: with percentage set to true, and a precision of 0 digits after the decimal point.

      • createPercentage

        public static StatisticalNumber createPercentage(java.lang.Number value1,
                                 java.lang.Number value2)
        a factory method for the creation of numbers representing percentages. Is an overloaded version of the single parameter version. Calculates the difference from value2 to value1.
        Example: 
         if value2 = 500, and value1 = 750, then the result is a
 StatisticalNumber representing 50%, because the growth from 500 to 750 is
 50%.
        Parameters:
        value1 - - a Number representing value1. Accepts null, but then the result is also null.
        value2 - - a Number representing value2. Accepts null, but then te result is also null.
        Returns:
        a StatisticalNumber which will be interpreted as a percentage, that is: with percentage set to true, and a precision of 0 digits after the decimal point.

      • createPvalue

        public static StatisticalNumber createPvalue(double value)
        A factory method for the creation of numbers representing p-values.
        Parameters:
        value - a double representing the p-value
        Returns:
        a StatisticalNumber which will be interpreted as a p-value, that is: with isPvalue set to true, and a precision of 3 digits after the decimal point.

      • scale

        public static java.lang.Number scale(java.lang.Number oldNumber,
                     double scaleFactor)
        allows for scaling of any Number, which is (for example) division by 1000.
        Parameters:
        oldNumber - a Number to be scaled. Can take any Number subclass.
        scaleFactor - a double indicating the number by which the values should be divided, for example 1000
        Returns:
        a new scaled Number. If the oldNumber param was...
        • null then a null is returned.
        • a StatisticalNumber:
          • if indicating a pvalue, then the oldNumber is returned.
          • if indicating a percentage, then the oldNumber is returned.
          • if indicating another StatisticalNumber, then value and error are scaled, but precision is the same.
        • any other Number then a scaled Double is returned.

      • hasEnoughData

        public boolean hasEnoughData()
        tests if the statisticalNumber has data. By definition it does not have data when:
        • it is marked as null
        • its value is null
        • its value is 0
        Returns:
        false if it does not have data according to the above definition, true otherwise.

      • hasErrorBar

        public boolean hasErrorBar()
        Returns:
        true if a confidence interval is defined for this number.

      • hasSymmetricalErrorBar

        public boolean hasSymmetricalErrorBar()
        Returns:
        true if a confidence interval is defined, and if this confidence interval is symmetrical. If no errorBar is defined, it returns false.
